conversation.content: [coldly] Six months and you finally show your face at this site again, probably because corporate forced you to sign off on the repairs.
Look, I don't need to explain myself to you—I submitted my designs according to code and if your crew had followed proper lockout procedures, nobody would have gotten hurt.
[bitter laugh] Right, blame the guys who trusted your specs, the ones that said the circuit was rated for half the actual load it was carrying.
The specifications were based on the information I was given by project management, and frankly, welders aren't qualified to evaluate electrical load calculations anyway.
Marcus lost two fingers, Sandra's got permanent nerve damage in her left arm, and Tommy still wakes up screaming from the nightmares. [quieter] But sure, tell me more about your paperwork.
Those injuries are unfortunate, but the investigation cleared me of any wrongdoing—the panel explicitly stated that multiple factors contributed to the incident.
[scathing] Multiple factors, yeah, like you cutting corners to meet deadlines and signing off on work you never actually inspected because you were too important to leave your office.
I inspected everything that was required by protocol, and I don't appreciate these accusations when you clearly don't understand the complexities of electrical system design.
I understand that three people trusted me to keep them safe and I failed them because I believed your signature meant something. [exhales] Won't make that mistake again.
[defensively] You want someone to blame because you can't accept that accidents happen in dangerous work environments, but targeting me won't change what happened.
Accidents happen when equipment fails randomly, not when an engineer specifies 60-amp breakers for a 120-amp load because he couldn't be bothered to verify the actual machinery specs.
[firmly] The machinery specifications provided to me indicated 60 amps, and I have the documentation to prove it—if someone changed the equipment later, that's not my responsibility.
That documentation you're hiding behind had the model number wrong, which anyone who actually looked at the equipment would have caught immediately.
Field verification wasn't part of my contracted scope, and honestly, if you were so concerned about safety, why didn't you raise these issues before the accident?
[seething] Because I trusted that someone with a master's degree and fifteen years of experience would know the difference between a 3-phase and single-phase motor rating.
The motor specifications in the database showed single-phase, and without a formal change order indicating otherwise, I had no reason to question it.
[flatly] You had no reason.

[exasperated] What do you want from me? An apology? An admission of guilt that my lawyers specifically advised against? I followed protocols, documented everything, and the company's insurance covered the damages.
I wanted you to care that your mistake destroyed people's lives, but clearly that's too much to ask from someone who thinks human suffering is just an insurance claim. [walking away]

[calling after] You think I don't care? I haven't designed a single system since without triple-checking every specification, but admitting fault means losing my license, my career, everything I've worked for—would that really help your crew?
